awd_titl_txt: Role of Extracellular Vesicles in Plant-Pathogen Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Plant diseases caused by viruses, bacteria, and fungi cause major economic harm to U.S. farmers and greatly limit agricultural production worldwide.  In developing regions such as sub-Saharan Africa and India, the combination of rapid population growth and declining agricultural production is a major threat to food security, and hence to political stability. There is thus an urgent need to improve the immune system of plants so that they can defend themselves against disease.  This project is focused on understanding an underappreciated component of the plant immune system that appears to be shared with humans, extracellular vesicles (EVs). EVs are microscopic spherical packages that can carry information from one cell to another within an organism.  Recent work in animal systems, including humans, has revealed that this information can reprogram recipient cells so that the receiving cell changes the proteins it produces, and hence the properties of the cell, and in some cases, the ability of a cell to prevent infection by a virus.  Recent work in the Innes laboratory indicates that EVs may serve a similar role in plants.   This research project aims to address basic questions about how plant EVs are produced, what they carry, and how they may contribute to plant immunity. The answers to these questions will facilitate development of disease resistant crops.  In addition, this project will provide hands on plant science activities to elementary, high school and undergraduate students, with a special focus on underrepresented minorities. 

This project focuses on the genesis and roles of extracellular vesicles (EVs) in the context of plant immune systems.  Although EV release by plant cells is known to be stimulated by fungal and bacterial infection, nothing is known about their function. Over the last two years, the Innes laboratory has developed a method for purifying and quantifying EVs from Arabidopsis leaves. Analysis of purified EVs revealed that they carry microRNAs and are highly enriched in proteins associated with response to biotic and abiotic stress, suggesting that EVs may participate in intercellular communication.   The experiments described in this proposal will address the following questions: 1) Does the protein and RNA content of plant EVs change in response to specific biotic stresses?  2) Are known endomembrane trafficking proteins required for production of plant EVs? 3) Are EVs required for host-induced gene silencing (HIGS) of genes in a fungal pathogen? Question 1 will be addressed using proteomic and RNA-seq analysis of EVs purified from Arabidopsis leaves following treatment with various biotic stresses. Question 2 will be addressed by quantifying EV production in mutant Arabidopsis lines deficient in specific endomembrane trafficking proteins. Question 3 will be addressed using a forward genetics screen to identify Arabidopsis mutants that are unable to perform HIGS of genes in the fungus Fusarium graminearum. This screen will uncover Arabidopsis genes required for HIGS, and will establish whether EVs transport small RNAs from the host to the pathogen. This award is co-funded by the Plant Biotic Interactions program in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems division and the Cellular Dynamics and Function program in the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences division.

por.por_cntn:
During infection of plant leaves by fungal pathogens, fungi form feeding structures to absorb nutrients from living cells. These feeding structures are called haustoria, and typically are tubular structures derived from the outer cellular membrane of a fungal cell pressed against, but not through, the outer cellular membrane of a plant cell (see Figure). The physical space between the fungal membrane and the plant membrane is considered extracellular since it is located outside both the fungal and plant cells. This extracellular space plays a critical role during the infection process, as all nutrients absorbed by the fungus must pass through this space. In addition, plants have active immune systems and respond to fungal infections by producing antimicrobial compounds. Such compounds must also pass through this extracellular space.

How nutrients and antimicrobial compounds move through the extracellular space is poorly understood. However, clues to this process have come from high magnification images of haustoria obtained using electron microscopy (see Figure). These images have revealed that the plant cellular membrane becomes highly evaginated, forming microscopic finger-like structures, with large numbers of vesicles (bubbles of cellular membrane) accumulating in this extracellular space. We refer to these as extracellular vesicles, or EVs. We hypothesized that EVs released by plant cells play an important role in transporting antimicrobial compounds to the fungus and thus represent a key component of the plant immune system. 

The objectives of this project were to:

1) Determine the protein and RNA content of EVs purified from plants challenged with pathogens or pathogen-derived signals.

2) Identify plant genes required for EV production.

3) Identify plant genes required for silencing of genes in fungal pathogens during infection, which involves transfer of short RNA molecules (21-24 nucleotides in length) from the host plant to the fungus. 

Outcomes:

Under objective 1, we discovered early in this project that EVs isolated from plants treated with salicylic acid, which induces strong biotic stress signaling, failed to show statistically significant changes in EV protein content. Based on this finding, we decided to drop further analysis of EV protein content, focusing our subsequent work on the RNA content of EVs. This focus led to our discovery that Arabidopsis plants secrete diverse long non-coding RNAs into the extracellular spaces of leaves, but surprisingly, we found that this RNA was located outside of EVs. Most notably, we discovered that plants secrete short RNAs associated with silencing of fungal genes, but that these were also mostly located outside of EVs and were associated with specific RNA-binding proteins. We thus concluded that EVs are unlikely to play a central role in transporting RNA from plant cells to fungal cells. This finding provides critical insight into approaches for using RNA-based mechanisms to protect crop plants from disease.

Under objective 2, we assessed the number EVs produced in leaves of Arabidopsis lines that carried loss-of-function mutations in 22 different genes. These genes were targeted based on their known roles in vesicle trafficking inside plant cells. Unfortunately, none of the mutant lines showed a statistically significant decrease in EV production. This result suggests that secretion of EVs is mediated by a mechanism that is distinct from the mechanisms that mediate trafficking of vesicles inside of cells. We also checked the EVs produced by these mutant lines for the presence of two known EV marker proteins. Significantly, we found one line that displayed an obvious decrease in these known EV proteins, suggesting that the mutated gene was involved in loading proteins into EVs. This discovery provides important insight into how proteins are loaded into EVs.  

Under objective 3, we generated transgenic lines of Arabidopsis that produced short interfering RNAs (21-24 nucleotides) that could base-pair with a specific messenger RNA (mRNA) in the fungal pathogen Colletotrichum higginsianum, which causes anthracnose disease on Arabidopsis. Base-pairing of these short RNAs to the fungal mRNA caused the fungal mRNA to be degraded, thus silencing the fungal gene. The fungal gene that we targeted is required by the fungus for infection, thus the transgenic Arabidopsis plants displayed enhanced resistance to infection by C. higginsianum. We then crossed this transgenic line to Arabidopsis mutant lines that carried mutations in known RNA binding proteins that we had shown under objective 1 to be present in the extracellular space. Significantly, mutations in two different genes encoding RNA binding proteins restored full susceptibility to our transgenic line, indicated that these RNA binding proteins are required for RNA transfer to the fungus. This discovery represents an important advance in our understanding of how plants can silence fungal genes.  

Over the course of this project four graduate students and four postdoctoral researchers received broad training in plant biology. These researchers and the project director also participated in multiple public outreach activities, including visiting third grade classrooms to lead hands-on experiments in plant biology.
